thread.title: NASA's Juno spacecraft captures images of Jupiter's moon Io, the most volcanic body in the solar system
thread.title_full: NASA's Juno spacecraft captures images of Jupiter's moon Io, the most volcanic body in the solar system

author: Jeff Stitt
title: NASA's Juno spacecraft captures images of Jupiter's moon Io, the most volcanic body in the solar system
text: NASA's Juno spacecraft captures images of Jupiter's moon Io, the most volcanic body in the solar system A NASA spacecraft is providing earthlings with an out-of-this-world look at what [NASA](/article/nasa-laser-message-beams-video-of-cat-back-to-earth/46175735) calls “the solar system’s most volcanic world.” NASA has released images of Jupiter’s moon Io after the [Juno](https://science.nasa.gov/mission/juno/) spacecraft, on Dec. 30, flew within 932 miles of the moon in the Jovian System. It’s the closest a spacecraft has come to Io in more than two decades, and is [Juno Mission's](/article/jupiter-s-mysteries-first-results-from-the-juno-mission/9932757) “closest-ever approach to Jupiter’s moon,” NASA said. “Juno captured Io’s molten surface and will return for another look in February,” [NASA said in a post on X, formerly known as Twitter.](https://twitter.com/NASA/status/1742310312571760843?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet) Scientists hope Juno’s flyby will help in better understanding the nature and diversity of the Jovian moon’s volcanoes, [according to an article published by NASA after the spacecraft flew by Io.](https://www.nasa.gov/missions/juno/nasas-juno-to-get-close-look-at-jupiters-volcanic-moon-io-on-dec-30/) Juno, an "orbiter," launched Aug. 5, 2011, and arrived at Jupiter in 2016 to explore the Jovian System, according to NASA's webpage dedicated to the mission and the craft. See some of the images NASA released in the video player above.
